questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravid woman at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She feels well. She has no personal history of serious illness. Medications include iron supplements and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F) and blood pressure is 108/60 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 24-week gestation. A 1-hour 50-g glucose challenge shows a glucose concentration of 155 mg/dL (N < 135). A 100-g oral glucose tolerance test shows glucose concentrations of 205 mg/dL (N < 180) and 154 mg/dL (N <140) at 1 and 3 hours, respectively. She refuses treatment with insulin. If the mother's condition is left untreated, evaluation of the infant after birth will most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infants born to diabetic mothers are at increased risk for polycythemia (Hct > 65%), not anemia. Fetal hyperinsulinemia results in an increased metabolic demand that can lead to fetal hypoxia and increased RBC production to compensate.

B) CORRECT:

Infants of mothers with diabetes are at risk for transient hypoglycemia. Because glucose is passively transferred through the placenta, persistently elevated glucose concentrations in the mother throughout pregnancy leads to hyperinsulinemia in the developing fetus in order to maintain euglycemia. After birth, the combination of high insulin levels and the cessation of high glucose transfer from the mother results in transient hypoglycemia. Insulin production may take several hours to days to return to physiological levels; therefore, infants may require exogenous glucose administration to prevent life-threatening complications.

C) INCORRECT:

Infants born to diabetic mothers are not at increased risk for developing an omphalocele. However, they are at increased risk for small left colon syndrome, which presents as the delayed passage of meconium.
Image Description:

Omphalocele: herniation of intraabdominal contents through an anterior abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord caused by the failure of the midgut to return to the abdominal cavity after its physiological herniation through the umbilical ring. Accordingly, the hernial sac is formed by the amniotic membrane and peritoneum, and the umbilical cord lies at the apex of the hernia.

Gastroschisis: a developmental defect of the anterior abdominal wall in the paraumbilical region through which intraabdominal contents prolapse. As it is the anterior abdominal wall that fails to develop correctly, there is no outer peritoneal or membranous covering.

Congenital umbilical hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through a patent umbilical orifice, which typically closes by 2 years of age. The sac of a paraumbilical hernia is the peritoneum.

Diastasis recti: an abnormally wide separation of the right and left rectus abdominis muscles. The abdominal fascia are intact. There is therefore no herniation, but a midline bulge is visible on straining (e.g., when trying to sit up).

D) INCORRECT:

Infants born to diabetic mothers are at increased risk for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, not dilated cardiomyopathy. Fetal hyperinsulinemia results in an increased metabolic demand that can lead to fetal hypoxia, triggering RBC production and redistribution of iron from cardiac tissue into hemoglobin. The combination of cardiac tissue iron deficiency and hypoxemia can impair cardiac modeling, usually in the septal regions, and cause hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Very low birth weight is a complication of various pregnancy-related conditions, including low calcium supplementation, premature delivery, and intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). Although infants born to mothers with pregestational diabetes are at an increased risk for IUGR, this patient has gestational diabetes, which is more commonly associated with fetal macrosomia as a result of excessive insulin secretion.

F) INCORRECT:

Potter sequence is a complication of intrauterine growth restriction, which can occur as a result of oligohydramnios. Infants born to diabetic mothers, however, have an increased risk for polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios; fetal hyperglycemia results in fetal polyuria and thus increased amniotic fluid.

G) INCORRECT:

Infants born to mothers with pregestational diabetes, not gestational diabetes, are at risk for caudal regression syndrome. This mother has no evidence of diabetes prior to pregnancy that would place her infant at increased risk for caudal regression syndrome.

H) INCORRECT:

Infants of diabetic mothers are at risk for hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia. Although the exact mechanism is not fully understood, it is thought that hypocalcemia may be due to abnormal maternal calcium-phosphorus metabolism, decreased concentrations of maternal vitamin D, and/or low levels of maternal magnesium levels that impair PTH release, which results in hypoparathyroidism. Routine screening for hypocalcemia is not performed in otherwise healthy infants born to mothers with diabetes.
questions.hint: Although most infants who develop this condition are asymptomatic, this abnormality could result in prolonged QTc, poor feeding, and even seizures.

questions.text: A 3-day-old male newborn develops several episodes of complete body shaking while at the hospital. The episodes last for about 10–20 seconds. He has not had a fever or trauma. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and has been healthy. The mother did not have routine prenatal care. There is no family history of serious illness. The patient appears irritable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows reddening of the face. His hematocrit is 68%. Neuroimaging of the head shows several cerebral infarctions. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Gestational diabetes mellitus leads to fetal hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinemia, thereby increasing the overall metabolic rate and oxygen demand of the fetus. Placental capacity is exhausted and hypoxemia develops, leading to increased erythropoiesis. Polycythemia develops, which can cause hyperviscosity syndrome after birth and may result in cerebral infarctions that lead to seizures. Hypoglycemia is also common in neonates born to mothers with gestational diabetes mellitus because of hyperinsulinemia that can persist in infants up to several days after birth. Additionally, hypocalcemia occurs more often in infants of diabetic mothers, although its mechanism is not entirely understood.

B) INCORRECT:

Microdeletion of chromosome 22 causes DiGeorge syndrome, which often manifests with cardiac abnormalities, abnormal face, thymus aplasia, cleft palate, and hypocalcemia (summarized by the acronym CATCH-22). Although the cause of this patient's polycythemia is also associated with hypocalcemia, none of these features are present. Additionally, DiGeorge syndrome would not explain this patient's polycythemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Early-onset (<5 days) neonatal infection with Listeria monocytogenes can manifest with seizures. However, this newborn lacks additional features of this infection, such as disseminated abscesses, respiratory distress syndrome, and meningitis. Moreover, Listeria infection is not associated with newborn polycythemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Maternal toxoplasmosis can lead to congenital toxoplasmosis, which can cause seizures. However, it also manifests with thrombocytopenia, purpuric rash, chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and/or intracranial calcifications, none of which are described in this patient. Additionally, congenital toxoplasmosis would not explain this patient's polycythemia.

E) INCORRECT:

A JAK2 mutation causes polycythemia vera. Although this patient's polycythemia, as well as the cerebral infarctions due to hyperviscosity syndrome, could be explained by this mutation, the mean age of onset for polycythemia vera is around 60 years of age. Moreover, JAK2 mutation is a somatic mutation, and therefore, it is extremely unlikely to be present in a 3-day-old newborn. Another cause of this patient's polycythemia is much more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Mutated factor V (also called Factor V Leiden) is the most common cause of hypercoagulability in white populations. Patients often present in early adulthood with repeat venous thromboembolism. However, factor V mutation is not associated with neonatal polycythemia.

G) INCORRECT:

Maternal consumption of alcohol during pregnancy causes fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FAS). However, unlike this patient, affected children present with dysmorphic features (smooth philtrum, thin upper lip, narrow forehead) and may have a cognitive delay. Moreover, FAS does not cause newborn polycythemia.

H) INCORRECT:

Maternal hypothyroidism leads to congenital hypothyroidism in infants. Although congenital hypothyroidism may cause polycythemia, this newborn lacks other characteristic features associated with this condition, such as prolonged newborn jaundice, hypotension, decreased activity, hoarse cry, and macroglossia.
questions.hint: This newborn's plethora (reddening of the face) and elevated hematocrit indicate neonatal polycythemia (Hct > 65%), which can lead to hyperviscosity syndrome and consequently cerebral infarctions (explaining this patient's seizures). The most likely cause of this patient's polycythemia is also associated with neonatal hypoglycemia and hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She feels well. Her earlier pregnancy was uncomplicated. This is her 4th prenatal visit. She had an ultrasound scan 2 weeks ago that showed a live intrauterine pregnancy consistent with a 22-week gestation with no anomalies. She had a normal Pap smear 2 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 24-week gestation. Her blood group and type is B positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Serum pregnancy-associated plasma protein A and hCG level
Swab for Group B streptococcus culture

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum pregnancy-associated plasma protein A and hCG levels (in combination with ultrasound measurement of nuchal translucency) are part of first-trimester screening for congenital abnormalities and are usually performed between 10–14 weeks' gestation.

B) CORRECT:

Screening for gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) with an oral glucose challenge test is recommended for every pregnant patient at 24–28 weeks' gestation, or earlier in patients with increased risk of undiagnosed type 2 diabetes (e.g., due to obesity and GDM in a previous pregnancy). Early diagnosis and treatment of gestational diabetes mellitus are important to prevent complications of this condition, including gestational hypertension, preeclampsia, and shoulder dystocia due to fetal macrosomia.

C) INCORRECT:

Rh antibody testing should be performed in all Rh-negative pregnant women between 28–29 weeks' gestation to screen for circulating Rh antibodies. Although screening can be performed earlier, Rh antibody testing is not necessary for this Rh-positive patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Screening for Group B streptococcus (GBS) by vaginal and rectal swab is performed at 36–37+6 weeks' gestation to evaluate for colonization that could potentially lead to neonatal infection or chorioamnionitis. Women who are positive for GBS should be treated with intrapartum penicillin G, or clindamycin or erythromycin in patients allergic to penicillin.

E) INCORRECT:

Biophysical profile is used to screen for pregnancies where there is an increased risk of antenatal fetal death. It is generally performed after 32 weeks' gestation.

F) INCORRECT:

Tdap vaccination is usually performed between 27–36 weeks' gestation, to booster maternal immunity to pertussis and to maximize the passive transfer of protective antibodies to the neonate.
questions.hint: At 24–28 weeks' gestation, screening for a condition associated with fetal macrosomia is recommended.

questions.text:
A 4800 g (10.6 lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 35-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. Significant lateral neck traction is required during delivery. Apgar scores are 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Vital signs are within normal limits. At rest, his right shoulder is adducted and internally rotated. The baby cries with passive movement of the arm. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
66%


Leukocyte count
9000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

142 mEq/L


 Cl-

103 mEq/L


 K+

5.1 mEq/L


 HCO3-

20 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
8 mg/dL


 Glucose

34 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.6 mg/dL


Which of the following maternal interventions is most likely to have prevented this infant's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Folate deficiency during pregnancy increases the risk of neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida, meningomyelocele, anencephaly, and encephalocele). Folate deficiency is not associated with macrosomia or hypoglycemia, and folic acid supplementation would not have prevented this patient's current symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Avoidance of soft cheeses and unpasteurized dairy during pregnancy is recommended to prevent infection with Listeria monocytogenes. Congenital Listeria infection can lead to granulomatosis infantiseptica and/or meningitis, as well as many other nonspecific symptoms, such as respiratory distress, fever, lethargy, difficulty feeding, and diarrhea. This patient's presentation is not consistent with congenital listeriosis, and avoidance of soft cheeses would not have prevented his current symptoms.

Listeriosis is one of the TORCH infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Penicillin is recommended for the treatment of prenatal Syphilis infection (a TORCH infection) in order to prevent congenital syphilis. Early congenital syphilis is characterized by hepatomegaly, jaundice, rhinorrhea, and skeletal abnormalities. Late congenital syphilis is characterized by facial abnormalities (e.g., saddle nose, frontal bossing), dental abnormalities (e.g., Hutchinson teeth, mulberry molars), interstitial keratitis, sensorineural hearing loss, and saber shin. This patient's presentation is not consistent with congenital syphilis.

D) CORRECT:

Exogenous insulin does not cross the placenta and therefore is the preferred agent for the treatment of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) after an unsuccessful trial of diet modification and exercise. GDM increases the risk of fetal macrosomia and consequently shoulder dystocia during vaginal delivery. Shoulder dystocia can result in an upper brachial plexus palsy. Maternal and fetal hyperglycemia also increases the risk for neonatal hypoglycemia (due to hyperinsulinemia) and neonatal polycythemia (due to chronic fetal hypoxia).

E) INCORRECT:

Prenatal alcohol exposure is associated with intrauterine growth restriction, developmental delay, and congenital birth defects such as microcephaly, midfacial hypoplasia, and cardiac defects (e.g., ventricular septal defect). Alcohol exposure is not associated with macrosomia, so abstinence would not have prevented this patient's current symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

In-utero exposure to cocaine causes vasoconstriction and increases risk of intrauterine growth restriction and morphologic defects in brain development. This can lead to decreased levels of arousal and developmental delay. The macrosomia seen in this patient is not consistent with cocaine exposure. Avoidance of cocaine would not have prevented this patient's current symptoms.

G) INCORRECT:

Avoiding exposure to cat feces (e.g., the cleaning of a pet's litter box) during pregnancy is recommended to prevent infection with Toxoplasma gondii. The classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes chorioretinitis (a form of posterior uveitis), diffuse intracranial calcifications, and hydrocephalus. This patient's presentation is not consistent with congenital toxoplasmosis, and avoidance of cat feces would not have prevented this patient's current symptoms.

Toxoplasmosis is one of the TORCH infections.

H) INCORRECT:

Vaccination against rubella is recommended to prevent congenital rubella syndrome. The classic triad of symptoms associated with congenital rubella syndrome consists of cataracts, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, and cardiac defects. A “blueberry muffin” rash may also be present. Rubella infection during pregnancy may result in intrauterine growth restriction, but it is not known to cause macrosomia.

Rubella is one of the TORCH infections; the risk of transmission is greatest during the first trimester of pregnancy.
questions.hint: This newborn has macrosomia (weight > 4000 g), polycythemia (hematocrit > 65%), and neonatal hypoglycemia (generally considered to be glucose < 50 mg/dL within the first 24 hours of birth), all of which suggest gestational diabetes.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravid woman at 25 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She has no history of serious illness and her only medication is a daily prenatal vitamin. A 1-hour 50-g glucose challenge shows a glucose concentration of 167 mg/dL (N < 135). A 100-g oral glucose tolerance test shows glucose concentrations of 213 mg/dL (N < 180) and 165 mg/dL (N < 140) at 1 and 3 hours, respectively. If she does not receive adequate treatment for her condition, which of the following complications is her infant at greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infants born to mothers with pregestational diabetes, not gestational diabetes, are at risk for intrauterine growth restriction. Infants born to mothers with gestational diabetes are at increased risk for macrosomia due to the anabolic effects of high insulin levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Infants of diabetic mothers are at risk for hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia. Although the exact mechanism is not fully understood, this type of hypocalcemia may be due to abnormal maternal calcium-phosphorus metabolism, and/or decreased maternal vitamin D concentrations. Infants of diabetic mothers are also at risk for hypomagnesemia due to maternal renal loss of magnesium from glycosuria. These low levels of magnesium can impair parathyroid hormone release, resulting in hypoparathyroidism that may also contribute to hypocalcemia.

C) CORRECT:

Hyperplasia of islet cells, the pancreatic cells responsible for producing insulin, can occur in utero in response to elevated maternal blood glucose levels, e.g., due to gestational diabetes. This can cause infantile hyperinsulinemia and put the infant at risk for hypoglycemia once the maternal placental transfer of glucose ceases after birth.

D) INCORRECT:

Infants born to diabetic mothers have an increased risk for polyhydramnios, or increased amniotic fluid, not oligohydramnios. Fetal hyperglycemia results in fetal polyuria and, thus, increased amniotic fluid production.

E) INCORRECT:

Untreated diabetes during pregnancy can have teratogenic effects, putting infants at increased risk for congenital malformations including hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and small left colon syndrome. They are not, however, at increased risk for omphalocele. Pregestational diabetes (but not gestational diabetes) puts infants at increased risk of caudal regression syndrome.

F) INCORRECT:

Infants born to diabetic mothers are at increased risk for polycythemia (Hct > 65%), not anemia. Fetal hyperinsulinemia results in an increased metabolic demand that can lead to fetal hypoxia and increased RBC production to compensate. Infants with polycythemia are at increased risk for RBC sludging, ischemia, and infarction.
questions.hint: Glucose readily crosses the placenta, meaning that elevated maternal glucose levels lead to elevated fetal blood glucose and, accordingly, cause physiologic changes that can lead to complications in the newborn infant.

questions.text: A stillborn infant is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation to a 32-year-old woman. The mother had no prenatal care. Examination of the stillborn shows a small pelvis, shallow intergluteal cleft, and club feet. An x-ray shows the absence of the sacrum and lumbar vertebrae. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Maternal oligohydramnios is associated with Potter sequence, which can result in club feet. However, Potter sequence does not typically result in lumbosacral agenesis or pelvic hypoplasia. Instead, pulmonary hypoplasia and other craniofacial abnormalities such as low-set ears, retrognathia, and a flattened nose would be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Fetal hydantoin syndrome may occur as a result of intrauterine phenytoin exposure. This condition manifests with neural tube defects, microcephaly, craniofacial defects (e.g., cleft lip/palate), and hypoplastic nails. Fetal hydantoin syndrome is not associated with lumbosacral agenesis or pelvic hypoplasia.

C) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine alcohol exposure can result in fetal alcohol syndrome, which manifests with features such as microcephaly, a smooth philtrum, thin vermillion border, small palpebral fissures, and congenital hip dislocation. This condition is not associated with lumbosacral agenesis or pelvic hypoplasia.

D) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) can result in club feet. However, affected infants do not typically have lumbosacral agenesis or pelvic hypoplasia. Instead, other features such as cleft lip, cleft palate, polydactyly, microphthalmia, and cutis aplasia would be expected.

E) CORRECT:

Caudal regression syndrome is strongly associated with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus during pregnancy. The exact mechanism driving this association, however, remains unclear. Other fetal anomalies associated with maternal diabetes include congenital heart disease (e.g., ventricular septal defect, transposition of great vessels), duodenal atresia, renal agenesis, cleft lip/palate, macrosomia or intrauterine growth restriction, polycythemia, neural tube defects, and transient neonatal hypoglycemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome) can result in club feet. However, affected infants do not typically have lumbosacral agenesis or pelvic hypoplasia. Furthermore, this infant lacks other characteristic features of trisomy 18, such as low-set ears, micrognathia, a prominent occiput, and clenched fists with overlapping fingers.
questions.hint: This stillborn infant's sacral deformity, small pelvis, and congenital foot deformity are highly characteristic of caudal regression syndrome.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician for a routine visit 5 days after she delivered a full-term 4050 g (8.9 lb) male infant. She reports occasional fatigue and numbness over her outer upper left thigh. Her pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes, treated with insulin during the second trimester. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable and her only medication is a multivitamin. She used to follow a strict vegetarian diet but since she became pregnant has started to eat chicken, fish, and dairy products. Her infant is exclusively breastfed and she reports no problems with nursing. She weighs 82 kg (181 lb) and is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall; BMI is 32 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows 1+ pitting edema in the lower extremities. There are some dilated, tortuous veins over both calves. Sensation to pinprick is decreased in the outer upper left thigh. Her hemoglobin concentration is 11.8 g/dL and her fasting blood glucose is 102 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 supplementation is indicated for patients with vitamin B12 deficiency, which may occur in women who do not consume animal products and in infants who are breastfed by women with vitamin B12 deficiency. This patient started consuming animal products when she became pregnant and has no signs of vitamin B12 deficiency (e.g., pallor, bilateral weakness, and bilateral upper and lower extremity paresthesias), making vitamin B12supplementation unnecessary.

B) CORRECT:

A one-step oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is indicated at 4–12 weeks postpartum for all women with a history of gestational diabetes. If OGTT is normal, a diabetes screening should be performed every 1–3 years. In addition, healthy lifestyle behaviors (e.g., regular exercise, healthy diet, and weight loss) should be discussed. In patients with a positive diabetes screening, T2DM can be diagnosed and should be treated accordingly. Prevention, early detection, and/or treatment of gestational diabetes reduces the risk of other complications such as metabolic syndrome and cardiovascular disease.

C) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the lumbosacral spine is indicated for women with atypical postpartum sensory neuropathy to rule out epidural hematoma, abscess, demyelination, and disk herniation. Decreased sensation in the left upper thigh suggests lateral femoral cutaneous nerve neuropathy, which is the most commonly injured nerve during labor. Most cases of postpartum neuropathy can be diagnosed without imaging and resolve spontaneously within the first 8 weeks postpartum. This patient has no signs of spine involvement or infection, making an MRI of the lumbosacral spine unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Usually, no further interventions are necessary after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. However, this patient has a history of gestational diabetes, which increases her risk of developing T2DM. Therefore, another approach is required.

E) INCORRECT:

Superficial venous ablation therapy is indicated for patients with symptomatic chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) that is unresponsive to conservative treatment. While pregnancy is a risk factor for the development of CVI, this patient is asymptomatic and she has not yet received any conservative treatment (e.g., leg elevation, exercise, and compression therapy), making a different step in management more appropriate.
questions.hint: Women who develop gestational diabetes have a higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in the future.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because they are concerned that he is not meeting his developmental milestones. He was born at term following spontaneous vaginal delivery. At birth, he was at the 80th percentile for height and weight. His mother has type 1 diabetes mellitus and sometimes forgot her insulin injections during pregnancy. Her HbA1c during pregnancy was measured at 9%. The boy is able to walk but cannot run, walk up stairs, or draw a line. He speaks in 1-word sentences and follows 1-step commands. He is currently at the 75th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination including neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. MRI of the head shows enlarged ventricles. After the physician discusses the imaging results with the parents, the father becomes angry and yells at his wife: “This is all your fault. I told you that you should have taken better care of your blood sugar during pregnancy.” Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: "There is no need to fight. We should be glad that we found this abnormality now."
"I can assure you that we are going to find out what caused your son's condition."
"This is not your wife’s fault. You should not yell at her."
"Even a few episodes of hyperglycemia can have deleterious effects on the unborn child."
"These findings can occur for many reasons. An elevated blood sugar is an unlikely cause."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

With this response, the physician would be imposing their opinion on the parents and telling them how they should feel. The physician should remain neutral and not voice their personal opinion about the family's conflict. Instead, they should invite the parents to share their thoughts and concerns.

B) INCORRECT:

This response gives the parents false reassurance, which should be avoided. Hydrocephalus may be idiopathic and a specific cause may ultimately not be found. Information given to patients and family members should be truthful and objective.

C) INCORRECT:

With this response, the physician aligns with the patient's mother. The physician should remain neutral in a family argument because taking sides may escalate the conflict and negatively affect patient care.

D) INCORRECT:

Although it is true that uncontrolled maternal hyperglycemia is associated with an increased risk of various complications in an embryo (e.g., caudal regression syndrome, neural tube defects, congenital heart disease) and fetus (e.g., macrosomia, polycythemia, respiratory distress syndrome) this response can intensify disagreement between the parents, causing more distress and potentially escalating the conflict. Physicians should remain neutral and not take the side of any of the parties involved.

E) CORRECT:

Diagnostic uncertainty may cause parents to feel responsible for their child's condition and can be a source of conflict. This response provides the parents with objective information in an honest and comprehensive manner. Information should be delivered clearly, using lay language, and avoiding false reassurance. When there is a conflict between family members, physicians should remain neutral and not take the side of any of the parties involved. A content-oriented and empathetic approach encourages family members to freely share their concerns and questions.

Maternal diabetes is associated with a higher risk of neural tube defects, which may manifest with congenital hydrocephalus. Because congenital hydrocephalus occurs during infancy when fontanelles are still open, patients present with macrocephaly. Hydrocephalus with a normal head circumference is usually due to an acquired condition (e.g., hemorrhage, CNS tumors, infections) occurring after 18 months of age. Therefore, maternal diabetes is an unlikely cause of this patient's findings.
questions.hint: Developmental delays (e.g., gross and fine motor skills, language), an MRI of the head showing enlarged ventricles, and a normal head circumference in a 2-year-old child suggest acquired hydrocephalus.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: No further management is indicated at this time
Perform an oral glucose tolerance test

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increasing iron supplementation can be necessary for iron deficiency anemia (IDA). This patient has an Hb of 11.5 g/dL, which is abnormal using regular cutoff values. However, diagnostic Hb levels for anemia during pregnancy should be used when assessing for IDA as there is an expected physiological decrease in hemoglobin during pregnancy due to increased plasma volume (i.e., dilutional anemia). Iron deficiency anemia in pregnancy is defined by an Hb < 11 g/dL in the first trimester. Increasing this patient's iron supplement is therefore not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has risk factors for GDM and requires further management.

C) INCORRECT:

Screening for thrombophilia is recommended in pregnant individuals at high risk of thrombophilic events (e.g., a history of unexplained thrombosis, recurrent miscarriage, or a strong family history of thrombotic events). However, routine screening is not recommended after a single miscarriage.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-D immunoglobulin prevents hemolytic disease of the newborn in pregnancies of Rhesus (Rh)-negative individuals with Rhesus (Rh)-positive fetuses. It is indicated for unsensitized Rh-negative pregnant individuals in any potentially sensitizing event (e.g., invasive prenatal diagnostic tests, miscarriage) or as a prophylactic starting at 28 weeks' gestation. However, this patient is Rh positive.

E) CORRECT:

Screening for GDM with an oral glucose tolerance test is typically performed toward the end of the second trimester, between 24 and 28 weeks' gestation. However, in patients with risk factors for GDM, earlier screening at the initial prenatal visit is recommended. If the initial screening is negative, oral glucose testing should be repeated with the recommended second-trimester laboratory studies.

Other risk factors for GDM include gestational diabetes during a previous pregnancy, recurrent pregnancy loss, and general risk factors for type 2 diabetes mellitus (e.g., polycystic ovary syndrome).
questions.hint: This patient has obesity, a prior pregnancy with fetal macrosomia, and a first-degree relative with type 2 diabetes, all of which are risk factors for gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
